Pursuant to LAW , international treaties on human rights and fundamental freedoms which have been ratified and promulgated in the manner required by statute take precedence over law .

All human beings are equal in dignity and rights ( LAW ) regardless of sex , race , colour , language , faith , religion , political affiliation or conviction , national or social origin , nationality or ethnic origin , property , birth or any other status . No one can be discriminated against , favoured or disfavoured on any of these grounds ( LAW ) .
Statutory restrictions on fundamental rights and freedoms must apply equally in all cases meeting given conditions ( LAW ) .

Pursuant to LAW , liberty of person is guaranteed and no one is to be prosecuted or deprived of liberty except for reasons and in a manner provided for by law . LAW permits a person ’s detention exclusively on grounds and for a period defined by law and on the basis of a court ’s decision .
Article CARDINAL guarantees persons accused of an offence time and facilities to prepare their defence and the right to defend themselves either in person or through counsel .

Under LAW , criminal liability for an act is assessed and the sentence is imposed pursuant to the law in force at the time when the offence was committed . PERSON enacted subsequently is to be applied where it is more favourable to the perpetrator .

Under DATE ORG , detention on remand was governed by the provisions of Articles CARDINAL et seq . A person charged with a criminal offence could be detained , inter alia , where there were reasonable grounds for believing that he or she would influence the witnesses or the co - accused or otherwise hamper the investigation ( LAW ( b ) ) or continue criminal activities , complete an attempted offence or commit an offence which he or she had prepared or threatened to commit ( LAW ( c ) ) .

The duration of detention was regulated by the provisions of Articles CARDINAL et seq . Detention on remand in the pre - trial phase of the proceedings and during the trial , taken together , could not exceed DATE . An extension could be authorised by ORG if it had been impossible to complete the proceedings earlier because of the complexity of the matter or for other important reasons and the release of the detainee would jeopardise the purpose of the proceedings . The total duration of the detention could not , however , exceed DATE or , in the case of offences qualified as extremely dangerous , DATE ( LAW ) .
The category of “ extremely dangerous offences ” was defined in LAW Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) and included rape .
The new Code of Criminal Procedure was enacted on DATE and its text was published in LAW . It entered into force on DATE . The duration of detention is regulated by ORG CARDINAL et seq .

The total duration of detention in the pre - trial phase of the proceedings and during the trial , taken together , can not exceed DATE where the case concerns a lesser crime ( prečin ) , DATE in the case of a crime ( zločin ) , and DATE in the case of an extremely serious crime ( obzvlášť závažný zločin ) ( LAW ) . Detention in the pre - trial phase of the proceedings and during the trial , taken separately , can last up to CARDINAL of the above periods ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . As regards detention during the trial , the period is to be counted from the moment when the bill of indictment is filed ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . The temporal application of DATE ORG is regulated by the provisions of Articles CARDINAL et seq . As a general rule , proceedings where the bill of indictment was filed prior to the entry into force of the DATE ORG should continue under DATE ORG ( LAW and CARDINAL ) . This includes proceedings in which the duration of and grounds for detention are examined ( LAW ) .

The provisions on the temporal application of the newly introduced DATE ORG initially gave rise to different interpretations by the benches of ORG . The criminal law section ( kolégium ) of ORG therefore adopted a standpoint indicating how LAW and LAW ORG should be interpreted ( case no . PERSON CARDINAL/CARDINAL , standpoint adopted on DATE and subsequently published in the Collection of standpoints of ORG and decisions of courts , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

With reference to LAW , LAW and LAW , the criminal law section of ORG held that persons who had been indicted prior to the entry into force of the DATE ORG were not entitled to have the duration of their detention as a whole or the duration of their detention during trial governed by LAW and DATE ORG . LAW ORG clearly indicated that that had not been the intention of the legislature . That situation did not amount to unequal treatment as the persons concerned had been remanded in detention under a different legal regime , namely that governed by DATE ORG .

However , both categories of detained persons – those whose detention was governed by DATE ORG and those detained under the DATE CCP – should receive equal treatment as regards the duration of their detention during trial after the entry into force of the DATE ORG . In practical terms , the detention during trial of persons falling within the former category in the period after DATE should not last longer than CARDINAL , CARDINAL or DATE , depending on the nature of the offence in issue , as specified in LAW ORG . In that respect those persons were treated equally to the other category of detainees . For example , the detention during trial of persons who had been remanded and indicted , prior to DATE , for offences which the DATE LAW qualified as extremely serious crimes could not exceed DATE as from DATE . Detention of such persons after DATE was therefore not permissible .
